title: 113_hr2166
content: The Act titled as the "Good Samaritan Search and Recovery Act" provides expedited access to certain federal lands. The Secretary will expedite access to Federal lands for eligible organizations and individuals to conduct Good Samaritan search-and-recovery missions. Access granted is for private purposes, not as Federal volunteers, and the Federal Torts Claim Act does not apply. The Federal Torts Claim Act and Federal Employee Compensation Act do not apply to eligible organizations or individuals conducting Good Samaritan search-and-recovery missions on Federal lands. Liability insurance is not required if they acknowledge and consent to specific provisions in writing. The Secretary must approve or deny requests for Good Samaritan search-and-recovery missions within 48 hours. If a request is denied, the eligible organization or individual will be notified of the decision. The Secretary must notify eligible organizations or individuals of the reason for denial requests and provide guidance on meeting requirements for approval. Partnerships with search-and-recovery organizations will be developed to coordinate missions on Federal lands. A report must be submitted within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will submit a joint report to Congress detailing plans for partnerships and efforts to expedite good Samaritan search-and-recovery missions for missing individuals on Federal lands. Definitions for "eligible organization" and "eligible individual" are provided for not-for-profit entities with certified training meeting ASTM standards. The curr_chunk defines terms like "good Samaritan search-and-recovery mission" and "Secretary" for the purpose of search operations on Federal lands. The curr_chunk states that the bill was passed by the House of Representatives on January 27, 2014.
